This doesn't answer your question, but why not just use PyGame?
PyGame makes it very to create draw 2d sprite based games.
There are actually two libraries that solve this, the older curses and the newer S-Lang.
Curses has a tendency to make buggy line art, especially on Windows and on unicode consoles (it's unicode support is shit).
S-Lang's screen management functions are better.

While I haven't used either of them in Python, and it seems curses is better supported, in C at least I'm switching my code to S-Lang because of those issues, and because deep down I never really liked the curses API.
It has a Windows Port and Unix Port, and plenty of documentation.
You can also use some helper libs.
One of the examples bundled with urwid is a simulator for animated bar graphs.
The bar graphs clear the screen well, without leaving artifacts of the old "frame".
